qas.question: What did Sir George Airy produce with the extra data?

plausible_answers.text: he requested extra data from Sir George Airy, the Astronomer Royal, who supplied it

context: In <a0_0>1821<a0_0/>, <b6_0><b9_0>Alexis Bouvard<b6_0/> published <b5_0>astronomical tables<b9_0/> of <a1_0>the <b10_0>orbit of Neptune's neighbour Uranus<b10_0/><b5_0/><a1_0/>. Subsequent observations revealed substantial deviations from the tables, leading Bouvard to hypothesise that an unknown body was perturbing the orbit through gravitational interaction. In <a2_0><b11_0>1843<b11_0/><a2_0/>, <b7_0>John Couch Adams<b7_0/> began work on the orbit of Uranus using the data he had. Via Cambridge Observatory director James Challis, <b13_0>he requested extra data from <a3_0><b12_0>Sir George Airy<b12_0/><a3_0/>, the Astronomer Royal, who supplied it<b13_0/> in February 1844. Adams continued to work in 1845–46 and produced <a4_0><b8_0>several different estimates of a new planet<a4_0/>.
